content:
Global warming may be to blame

SPARE A THOUGHT for the zebras in Chicago’s zoo. The creatures looked ill-equipped while clomping through the snow in sub-zero temperatures this month. The Windy City is enduring exceptionally cold weather. Forecasts suggest -31°C (-24°F) is likely on January 30th. Given the strong breezes whipping off a part-frozen Lake Michigan, that could feel more like -48°C. Schools and some offices have closed. The last time it was so frosty was a generation ago, and records could even be broken. The situation is similar across the Midwest. Universities have cancelled classes. Residents in many towns and cities have been warned to stay inside, or risk the rapid onset of frostbite. Wisconsin has declared a state of emergency, in part because of heavy snow. Although chilly winters are nothing new, the freeze this year looks unusually severe. The cause is changing air currents. But what explains them, why do they make the region so cold, and how should people cope?

Two sets of air currents determine which parts of North America and Europe get blasted by Arctic air each winter. The stratospheric polar vortex is a smallish patch of low-pressure air that circulates, anti-clockwise, in a ring some 48km (30 miles) above the Arctic. It helps to trap the coldest air near the pole and forms only in winter. A second current, the polar jet stream, flows all year round, at an altitude of about 11km, and covers a much larger area. It is affected both by the temperatures and air pressure in different parts of the globe, and by the spinning of the Earth. When the Arctic is cold and lower latitudes are reliably warm, the jet stream is more stable. The problem for America’s Midwest is that the Arctic has warmed unusually fast, a result of more greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, and so the polar jet stream is fluctuating more widely. As a result, the stratospheric polar vortex may slow down, and colder air is drawn southwards. A similar sort of shift in the air currents helped to cause the “Beast from the East” that chilled western Europe in 2018.

Is man-made climate change therefore the cause of disruption to the polar vortex? It is not yet proven beyond dispute, but some climate scientists see evidence building up. For example, Jiankai Zhang at Cambridge University and colleagues have argued in Nature Climate Change , a journal, that the loss of ice in the Barents-Kara seas, combined with increased snowfall in Eurasia, contributed to the slowdown of the Arctic polar vortex over the past three decades—and thus colder spells farther south. They warned that the “persistent sea-ice loss in the future and its associated climatic impact” are not sufficiently understood, but could suggest more changes are coming. The fact that polar sea-ice is melting faster than many climate scientists had previously expected (because of climate change) could suggest the dramatic cold spells suffered by Chicago and other cities this week will become more common.

How do residents cope? For most, the extreme cold is a temporary inconvenience. It gives them a common topic of conversation and causes some annoyances—higher heating bills, cancelled flights, closed schools and more perilous roads. Restaurants and taxis typically lose business, but services that deliver takeaway food get a boost. For the elderly and for poorer and homeless residents the consequences are far more severe. The city of Chicago provides warm shelters, though newspapers have already reported some individuals’ deaths from hypothermia. In the long run, a wider change is possible. More extreme winters could hasten the steady decline in the populations of both Chicago and Illinois, as the young head to cities on the coasts, while older residents turn their eyes to retirement in sunny Florida. Pity the zebras, then. It’s rather harder for them to move on.

Dig deeper

Jet set: Is polar warming to blame for America’s and Britain’s bad winter weather? (February 2014)

eg2: As one local  put it in May, "By day there is government.
正如一位当地居民在五月份对它的描述”白天有政府。
Almost every Resident is a tenant of the duchy, which has its regional office in the village.
这里几乎所有居民都是公国的住户，公国在村子里设有区域办事处。
Few of her former comrades enjoy this comfort; but, as another Resident explained, the authorities like them to live there "to do propaganda and education work".
她以前的同志，很少人能享受能这种舒适生活；不过另一个居民解释说，当局希望他们住在那以“进行宣传教育工作”。

ex: v. 交往；联想；联系；（尤指）混在一起

eg2: I always associate the smell of baking with my childhood.
一闻到烘烤食物的味道，我就想起了童年。
He is closely associated in the public mind with horror movies.
在公众的心目中，他总是和恐怖电影紧密联系在一起。
I don't like you associating with those people.
我不喜欢你和那些人混在一起。
I associate myself with the Prime Minister's remarks(= I agree with them) .
我赞同首相所言。

ex: n. 爆炸；冲击波；狂欢；突如其来的强劲气流
v. 爆破；把…炸成碎片；轰鸣（尤指音乐）；严厉批评
int. （恼怒时说）该死
网络 一阵；鼓风；疾风
eg2: a bomb blast
炸弹爆炸
27 schoolchildren were injured in the blast.
27 名学龄儿童在爆炸中受了伤。
A blast of hot air hit us as we stepped off the plane.
我们下飞机时，一股热浪向我们袭来。
the wind's icy blasts
凛冽的狂风
three short blasts on the ship's siren
船上三次短促的汽笛声
Blast for prison governors in judge's report
法官报告中对典狱长猛烈抨击
The party was a blast.
聚会非常热闹。
We had a blast at the party.
我们在聚会上玩得很开心。
She had the car stereo on at full blast.
她把汽车音响开到了最大音量。
She had the car stereo on at full blast.
她把汽车音响开到了最大音量。
They blasted a huge crater in the runway.
他们在飞机跑道上炸了一个大坑。
They had to blast a tunnel through the mountain.
他们得炸出一条穿山隧道。
All the windows were blasted inwards with the force of the explosion.
爆炸的震动力把所有窗户都震碎到屋里。
The jumbo jet was blasted out of the sky.
那架巨型喷气式飞机在空中被炸成碎片。
Danger! Blasting in Progress!
危险！爆破进行中！
Music suddenly blasted out from the speakers.
喇叭中突然响起了轰鸣的音乐。
The radio blasted out rock music at full volume.
收音机以最大音量播放摇滚乐。
The movie was blasted by all the critics.
这部影片受到了所有评论家的严厉抨击。
He blasted the ball past the goalie.
他飞脚将球踢过了守门员。
He blasted(= shot) the policeman right between the eyes.
他对着那个警察的眉心开了一枪。
Police blasted the demonstrators with water cannons.
警察用高压水炮喷射示威者。
Their whole crop had been blasted by a late frost.
一场晚霜把他们的庄稼全毁了。
Oh blast! The car won't start.
真该死！车子发动不了。

eg2: The report calls for farming to focus on crops and livestock that do "reasonably well" in a variety of environments rather than those that excel in a narrow set of  conditions.
该报告呼吁农业把重点放在能在多种环境上生长得很好的作物和牲畜，而非把重点放在那些在少数气候条件下长得很好的品种。
The focus will be on how agriculture can continue to produce adequate quantities of food for the world’s growing population, and particularly the poor and vulnerable, in changing climatic conditions.
会议的重点将是在不断变化的气候条件下，农业如何能够持续为世界不断增长的人口，尤其是贫困和弱势人口生产足够的粮食。

eg2: a town on the south coast of England

islands off the west coast of Ireland
爱尔兰西海岸的岛屿
a trip to the coast
海滨旅游
We walked along the coast for five miles.
我们沿着海岸步行了五英里。
the Welsh coast
威尔士海岸
a pretty stretch of coast
一段美丽的海岸线
the coast road
滨海道路
As soon as the coast was clear he climbed in through the window.
等到四下无人，他便从窗户爬了进去。
As soon as the coast was clear he climbed in through the window.
等到四下无人，他便从窗户爬了进去。
The car coasted along until it stopped.
汽车随惯性而下直至滑行停止。
She took her feet off the pedals and coasted downhill.
她把脚从自行车的踏板上抬开，沿山坡滑行而下。
The plane coasted down the runway.
飞机顺着跑道平稳滑行。
He coasted through his final exams.
他毫不费劲地通过了期终考试。
You're just coasting─it's time to work hard now.
你根本是在应付，现在该努力干了。

ex: adj. 更冷的，越来越冷的（cold的比较级）

网络 影响；推论；结局
eg2: This decision could have serious consequences for the industry.
这项决定可能对该行业造成严重后果。
Two hundred people lost their jobs as a direct consequence of the merger.
合并一事直接导致二百人失去了工作。

他开车太快，结果酿成惨剧。
to suffer/face/take the consequences of your actions
自食其果；面对╱承担自己行动的后果
Don't worry. It's of no consequence .
别担心，这无关紧要。

ex: v. 处理

ex: n. 破坏，毁坏；分裂，瓦解
eg2: He could draw men round him and keep them bound to him; while his powerful attraction was there,  was out of the question.
他能够把人们吸引到他的周围而且保持他们的忠心；而他的强大吸引力所在之处，就不可能有分裂。
Part of the genius of capitalism is its ability to adjust to disruption from within and attacks from without.
资本主义的一个好处在于它有能力从内部调整分裂，又能从外部适应攻击。
This region, in particular, knows the costs and disruption caused by outbreaks of dengue and Japanese encephalitis.
这个区域尤其了解登革热和日本脑炎暴发所造成的费用和破坏。

ex: n. 紧急情况；突发事件；非常时刻

ex: vt. 忍耐；容忍
vi. 忍耐；持续
eg2: I cannot endure your insults any longer.
我再也不能容忍你的侮辱。
If you wish to remain in our company, you must endure this.
如果你想和我们一起呆在这的话，那你就必须忍耐。
But, beyond the end of our combat mission, we will still have a partnership with Afghanistan, a partnership that will .
但是，我们战争的使命结束后，我们跟阿富汗依然还有合作关系，这种合作关系将会持续下去。

ex: v. 装备；预备（equip的过去分词）；整装

wp.Equipped capacitor: 生产能力;装机容量;主机功率
wp.simply equipped: 设备简陋的;设施不完备的

eg2: The army is very poorly .
这支部队装备很差。
They had equipped their workers adequately for such dangerous condition.
他们让工人们充分装备起来， 以应付这样的危险情况。
Teachers, though, see hundreds of children in the same age group, and they are well- to determine the readiness of their students and provide appropriate curriculum.
但是，教师看到在同年龄组中的数百名儿童，他们已装备得很好，以确定他们学生的准备，并提供适当的课程。

wp.extremely exceptionally: 您这汉语说得倍儿棒啊

ex: adv. 异常地；特殊地；例外地
eg2: It possesses incredible strength and elasticity, while its exceptionally high conductivity and use in flexible semiconductors could soup up computing.
它具有难以置信的强度和弹性，而其异常的高导电性和半导体中灵活的应用可以提高计算能力。
Though nearly 50, he is  vigorous in work.
别看他快50岁了， 工作却是雷厉风行。
I want to pay tribute to all those working in these exceptionally difficult situations.
我要向所有在这些极端困难境况下工作的人们致以敬意。

ex: vi. 波动；涨落；动摇
vt. 使波动；使动摇
eg2: The latest data continue to show that suicide statistics in the Army frequently .
最近的数据进一步表明，军队中的自杀统计结果经常波动。
The problem with this method is that methane and nitrous oxide emissions fluctuate strongly in time and space.
这种方法的问题是，甲烷和一氧化氮的排放量在不同时间和空间波动很大。
Banks usually need to be much more cautious about such lending as commodity prices fluctuate far more than property prices.
通常银行要对这种贷款更为小心，因为大宗商品价格的波动远甚不动产价格。

ex: vt. 使冻伤；使受霜害
vi. 参加冬季帆船比赛

wp.Treat frostbite: 治疗冻伤;治疗冻疮;拿掉湿掉的服装

ex: adj. 结霜的，严寒的；冷淡的；灰白的
eg2: A spokesman for the league gave the proposals a frosty reception.
联赛的一位发言人给了这些提议一个冷淡的回应。
